Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Particle Dynamics: Swimming Cells and Sheared Particulate Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
*****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT*****
This project utilizes the tracking of particles and cells for novel investigations of complex nonlinear systems. One project is a study of the fluid dynamics of swimming single celled swimming organisms that utilize molecular motors contained within twin flagella to propel themselves through a fluid. Investigations are planned of the induced velocity fields and mixing produced by swimming cells, their interactions with each other, collective behavior, the mechanics of the deforming flagella, and the confinement of cells by light. This work will extend our understanding of the fluid dynamics and statistical physics of microorganisms. A second investigation explores the deformation and failure of sheared layers of cohesive particles, which provides a promising model system for understanding the mechanical failure of disordered solids. This work includes the training of undergraduate investigators learning how to conduct independent research and postdoctoral scholars learning how to mentor students successfully. The work on swimmers is connected to certain diseases involving abnormalities of flagellar function, and the work on failure modes of packings can contribute to the improvement of particulate-based materials.

*********NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT*********
This project utilizes the video tracking of particles and biological cells for novel investigations of complex systems. One project explores the behavior of swimming single-celled organisms that utilize molecular motors contained within protrusions called flagella to propel themselves through the surrounding fluid. This work may eventually lead to insight into diseases involving abnormalities of flagellar function. Investigations are planned of the fluid mixing produced by swimming cells, their interactions with each other, the deformations of their flagella, and their confinement by light. A second investigation studies the deformation and breaking of layers of cohesive particles, which could contribute to the design of solids that are especially strong. All of this work includes undergraduate investigators learning how to conduct independent research and postdoctoral scholars learning how to mentor students successfully. The Principal Investigator is also deeply involved in projects designed to improve undergraduate physics education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mian goal of this project is to study of the fluid dynamics of swimming single celled swimming organisms that utilize molecular motors contained within twin flagella to propel themselves through a fluid. Investigations are planned of the induced velocity fields and mixing produced by swimming cells, their interactions with each other, collective behavior, and the mechanics of the deforming flagella. We expect that this this work will extend our understanding of the fluid dynamics and statistical physics of of a new class of systems, namely active matter. The project is highly interdisciplinary and includes the training of undergraduate investigators learning how to conduct independent research and postdoctoral scholars learning how to mentor students successfully.

We made quite a bit of progress in understanding the flow and swimming behavior of algal cells, particularly in more realistic biological fluids that often possess some level of elasticity such a mucus. We showed the the ciliary beating in viscoelastic materials (e.g. mucus) is quite different from the beating in water even when adjusted by viscosity.

Also, we found that, unlike systems that are thermally equilibrated, the diffusion of (passive) particles and (bath) temperature of bacterial suspensions depend non-monotonically on particle size. In other words, the temperature of the bath (in this case bacterial suspension) depends on the size of the thermometer, which is not typical of systems in equilibrium. A regime was found in which a large particle would diffuse (or move) faster than a small particle.

Another interesting result is that the run-and-tumble mechanism often associated with bacterial swimming is strongly affected by the fluid properties. In particular, we found that E. coli tumbles less as viscosity increases and swim faster as fluid elasticity increases.
